template.name: Default Template
template.description: The default lexicon structure of LEXUS 2.

export.name: export-temp-1
export.description: Converting relissh ll lmf to relish lmf

container.description: The container for all the lexical entries of a source language within the database. A Lexicon must contain at least one lexical entry
container.name: Lexicon

update.info: Updating this container will make it a lexicon specific extension of the LMF model.

create.warning: Creating a container will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

update.warning: Updating this container will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

delete.warning: Deleting this container will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

update.warning: Updating this data category will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

delete.warning: Deleting this data category will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

container.description: Represents a word, a multi-word expression, or an affix in a given language
container.name: Lexical Entry

update.warning: The LMF core model requires a Form subclass, i.e., Lemma. Changing this data category will disable the RELISH LMF export.

delete.warning: The LMF core model requires a Form subclass, i.e., Lemma,Word Form or Stem. These are all defined in the Morphology extension where Lemma is mandatory.

container.description: Represents one lexical variant of the written or spoken form of the lexical entry
container.name: Form

update.warning: The LMF core model requires a Form subclass, i.e., Lemma. Changing this data category will disable the RELISH LMF export.

delete.warning: The LMF core model requires a Form subclass, i.e., Lemma, Word Form or Stem. These are all defined in the Morphology extension where Lemma is mandatory.

datacategory.description: Main word of the lexical entry
datacategory.name: Lexeme

container.description: Contains attributes that describe meanings of a lexical entry
container.name: Sense

export.name: temp a export format 1
export.description: cpnverting template a to froamt a

export.name: temp a export format 2
export.description: cpnverting template a to froamt b

container.description: The container for all the lexical entries of a source language within the database. A Lexicon must contain at least one lexical entry
container.name: Lexicon

container.description: Represents a word, a multi-word expression, or an affix in a given language
container.name: Lexical Entry

container.description: Represents a word form chosen by convention to designate the Lexical Entry
container.name: Lemma

container.description: Represents one variant orthography of a Form for a Lemma
container.name: Form Representation

datacategory.description: Represents the written form of the Form Representaion for Lemma
datacategory.name: written form

container.description: Contains attributes that describe meanings of a lexical entry
container.name: Sense

container.description: Represents a narrative description of a Sense
container.name: Definition

container.description: Represents one textual content of Definition
container.name: Text Representation

datacategory.description: the actual text
datacategory.name: text

container.description: The container for all the lexical entries of a source language within the database. A Lexicon must contain at least one lexical entry
container.name: Lexicon

container.description: Represents a word, a multi-word expression, or an affix in a given language
container.name: Lexical Entry

container.description: Represents one lexical variant of the written or spoken form of the lexical entry
container.name: Lexeme Group

datacategory.description: The Record marker for each record in a lexical entry. It contains the lexeme or headword (which is commonly mono-morphemic). Since such a lexeme form is often not accessible for vernacular speakers if printed, use the \lc field to provide a more readable form for vernacular speakers.
datacategory.name: Lexeme

datacategory.description: Used to differentiate homonym entries (lexemes that are spelled the same but have no semantic relationship). This field comes directly after the \lx field and simply contains a number, e.g. 1, 2, or 3, etc. Use a Character Range Set.
datacategory.name: Homonym number

datacategory.description: phonetic form of the main entry
datacategory.name: Phonetic form

datacategory.description: part of speech of the main entry
datacategory.name: Part of Speech

datacategory.description: definition of the main entry
datacategory.name: Definition

datacategory.description: additional note
datacategory.name: note

template.name: MDF
template.description: The default lexicon structure for MDF

container.description: Represents the entire lexicon
container.name: Lexicon

container.description: Represents a word, a multi-word expression, or an affix in a given language
Group added for marker 'lx'
container.name: Lexeme Group

datacategory.description: The Record marker for each record in a lexical entry. It contains the lexeme or headword (which is commonly mono-morphemic). Since such a lexeme form is often not accessible for vernacular speakers if printed, use the \lc field to provide a more readable form for vernacular speakers.
datacategory.name: Lexeme

datacategory.description: Alternate form of lexeme for use in parsing interlinear text. Not for publication.
datacategory.name: Alternate for parse

datacategory.description: A Shoebox bookkeeping field to help keep track of the last time an entry was edited. One per record (usually the last field) is adequate. Usually inserted automatically by Shoebox. The datestamp field is set up under the Shoebox menu option: Database-Properties-Options tab.
datacategory.name: Date (last edited)

datacategory.description: Used to differentiate homonym entries (lexemes that are spelled the same but have no semantic relationship). This field comes directly after the \lx field and simply contains a number, e.g. 1, 2, or 3, etc. Use a Character Range Set.
datacategory.name: Homonym number

datacategory.description: This should be added only if the lexical entry form is inappropriate for the printed dictionary, and you want to substitute another form for the printed entry. When formatting a document, MDF always replaces the contents of the \lx field with the contents of the \lc field (if present).
datacategory.name: Citation form

container.description: Group added for marker 'se'
container.name: Subentry Group

datacategory.description: Like the \lx field except it occurs within the record, marking a word (or phrase) as a form derived from the root. Following this marker would be all the fields that comprise a typical lexical entry. There can be several of these subentries within a record. Subentries can have multiple senses (in this hierarchy).
datacategory.name: Subentry

datacategory.description: Used for denoting the source language of a borrowed word.
datacategory.name: Borrowed word (loan)

container.description: Group added for marker 'et'
container.name: Etymology (proto form) Group

datacategory.description: The etymology for the lexeme is put here, e.g.: \et *babuy
datacategory.name: Etymology (proto form)

datacategory.description: Any comments the researcher needs to add concerning the etymology of the lexeme can be given here. Not intended for printing.
datacategory.name: Etymology comment

datacategory.description: The published gloss for the etymological reference is given here.
datacategory.name: Etymology gloss (E)

datacategory.description: The reference or source abbreviation for etymology of the lexeme is given here. Use a Range Set.
datacategory.name: Etymology source

datacategory.description: Used to reference a minimal entry back to its main entry.
datacategory.name: Main entry cross-ref.

datacategory.description: Used to show the underlying morphemic structure for complex lexemes.
datacategory.name: Morphology

datacategory.description: Used as needed to retain the phonetic information that is lost when an orthographic spelling is used for an entry. Can follow \lx or \se. Details on how to interpret symbols in this field should be included in pronunciation guide.
datacategory.name: Phonetic form

container.description: Group added for marker 'ps'
container.name: Part of speech Group

datacategory.description: Classifies the part of speech. This must reflect the part of speech of the vernacular lexeme (not the national or English gloss). Consistent labeling is important; use the Range Set feature. Sense numbers are beneath \ps in this hierarchy; don't mark different \ps fields with sense numbers.
datacategory.name: Part of speech

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: First dual

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: First plural exclusive

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: First plural inclusive

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: First plural

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: First singular

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Second dual

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Second plural

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Second singular

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Third dual

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Third plural

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Third singular

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Non-animate dual

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Non-animate plural

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular for this particular paradigm form. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Non-animate singular

container.description: Group added for marker 'pd'
container.name: Paradigm Group

datacategory.description: Used for specifying the noun or verb class, gender, or other paradigm set that the lexeme or headword is associated with. These classes are generally given labels or numbers to differentiate them. Use the Range Set feature for consistency.
datacategory.name: Paradigm

container.description: Group added for marker 'pdl'
container.name: Paradigm label Group

datacategory.description: Used to label the paradigm form given in the \pdv field. This is useful for paradigm sets that are incomplete or irregular. Use a Range Set.
datacategory.name: Paradigm label

datacategory.description: Used for glossing the vernacular paradigm form in English.
datacategory.name: Paradigm form gloss (E)

datacategory.description: Used for glossing the vernacular paradigm form in the national language.
datacategory.name: Paradigm form gloss (n)

datacategory.description: Used for glossing the vernacular paradigm form in the regional language.
datacategory.name: Paradigm form gloss (r)

datacategory.description: Used to give the vernacular paradigm form specified by the label in the \pdl field. Used mostly for irregular or incomplete paradigm sets.
datacategory.name: Paradigm form

datacategory.description: This is a special paradigm field used to give the plural form of the lexeme. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Plural form

datacategory.description: Classifies the part of speech with labels found in national language dictionaries. If used, this comes after the \ps field. Consistent labeling is important; use the Range Set feature.
datacategory.name: Part of speech (n)

datacategory.description: A repository for reduplication forms for later study (these forms should be moved to subentries, etc. as more is known about them).
datacategory.name: Reduplication form(s)

datacategory.description: This is a special paradigm field used to give the singular form of the lexeme. (It is better to use the \pdl field set for this.)
datacategory.name: Singular form

container.description: Group added for marker 'sn'
container.name: Sense number Group

datacategory.description: Where a lexeme has more than one sense, this code is used to mark and number mark the beginning of each section that discusses a new sense. Don't use a sense number to mark a different part of speech; \sn is only used within a given part of speech (in this hierarchy). (Remember to include \sn 1 for records with multiple senses.) Use a Character Range Set.
datacategory.name: Sense number

datacategory.description: Used to reference an antonym of the lexeme, but using the \lf (lexical function) field for this is better practice.
datacategory.name: Antonym

datacategory.description: Used to record any bibliographic information pertinent to the lexeme. MDF adds the label 'Read:' to this field. For basic information (to reference an entry in a more complete bibliography database) include the following: AuthorLastName, FirstName/Initials date:pp. For a more complete reference include: AuthorLastName, FirstName/Initials. date. Title. City, Publisher. pp. xxx-yyy.
datacategory.name: Bibliography

container.description: Group added for marker 'cf'
container.name: Cross-reference Group

datacategory.description: This is a generic reference marker used to link together any two related entries in the lexicon. The content is a vernacular lexeme. If the relationship is known, the lexical function \lf field is a better way to cross-reference two lexemes.
datacategory.name: Cross-reference

datacategory.description: Gives the English gloss(es) for the vernacular lexeme referenced by the preceding \cf field.
datacategory.name: Cross-ref. gloss (E)

datacategory.description: Gives the national language gloss(es) for the vernacular lexeme referenced by the preceding \cf field.
datacategory.name: Cross-ref. gloss (n)

datacategory.description: Gives the regional language gloss(es) for the vernacular lexeme referenced by the preceding \cf field.
datacategory.name: Cross-ref. gloss (r)

datacategory.description: Used to fully express the semantic domains of each sense of a lexeme in English. May be verbose. Other fields (\ee, \ue, and \oe) provide for expanded information. Should contain 1) the bundle of semantic distinctive features necessary and sufficient to describe its core meaning, and 2) the range of denotation of the lexeme. Generally, no initial capital is used.
datacategory.name: Definition (E)

datacategory.description: Used to fully express the semantic domains of each sense of a lexeme in the national language. May be verbose. Other fields (\en, \un, and \on) provide for expanded information. Should contain 1) the bundle of semantic distinctive features necessary and sufficient to describe its core meaning, and 2) the range of denotation of the lexeme. Generally, no initial capital is used.
datacategory.name: Definition (n)

datacategory.description: Used to fully express the semantic domains of each sense of a lexeme in the regional language. May be verbose. Other fields (\er, \ur, and \or) provide for expanded information. Should contain 1) the bundle of semantic distinctive features necessary and sufficient to describe its core meaning, and 2) the range of denotation of the lexeme. Generally, no initial capital is used.
datacategory.name: Definition (r)

datacategory.description: The hardest of all fields to fill in. It requires the researcher to explain, in the vernacular, what the salient concepts are that this "unit of meaning" captures -- from a native speaker's perspective. Obviously not easy and something usually left to much later.
datacategory.name: Definition (v)

datacategory.description: This field crosses over with the \de, \ue, and \oe fields, but is intended for more verbose explanations of the headword (for each sense). The researcher should use this field to encode any additional information needed by a non-native speaker to understand and use this lexeme properly. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Encyclopedic info. (E)

datacategory.description: The national language equivalent to the \ee field. It should cover any information that provides a more complete knowledge-base on the lexeme. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Encyclopedic info. (n)

datacategory.description: The regional language equivalent to the \ee field. It should cover any information that provides a more complete knowledge-base on the lexeme. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Encyclopedic info. (r)

datacategory.description: This field contains the vernacular description of any pertinent encyclopedic information related to the lexeme or headword, subentry, or sense. This is intended for use in a monolingual dictionary, but can be used in diglot and triglot dictionaries as well. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Encyclopedic info. (v)

datacategory.description: Intended for interlinear morpheme-level glossing. Join multi-word glosses with (_), e.g. wild_boar; use (space semicolon space) for multiple glosses, e.g. hut ; house ; shack. Used for reversing the dictionary if an \re field is not present (or is present but empty); also as an English definition in a formatted dictionary if there is no \de field (or it is present but empty).
datacategory.name: Gloss (E)

datacategory.description: Intended for interlinear morpheme-level glossing. Join multi-word glosses with (_), e.g. wild_boar; use (space semicolon space) for multiple glosses, e.g. hut ; house ; shack. The contents are used for reversing the dictionary if an \rn field is not present (or is present but empty). Also used as a national language definition in a formatted dictionary if there is no \dn field (or it is present but empty).
datacategory.name: Gloss (n)

datacategory.description: Intended for interlinear morpheme-level glossing. Join multi-word glosses with (_), e.g. wild_boar; use (space semicolon space) for multiple glosses, e.g. hut ; house ; shack. Since MDF does not create a reversed index for the regional language, this field is not used for this. But the contents of this field are used as a regional language definition in a formatted dictionary if there is no \dr field (or it is present but empty).
datacategory.name: Gloss (r)

datacategory.description: This field is available for developing a monolingual dictionary. While somewhat meaningless (a vernacular gloss for a vernacular word), this is a useful place to store the explanations a researcher is given by a language assistant concerning the meaning of the headword or lexeme. Later these will be formulated into a more exact definition and transfer to the \dv field.
datacategory.name: Gloss (v)

datacategory.description: Used to catalog lexical entries according to an etic (published) list of possible semantic domains. Sorting on this field would then gather semantically related entries. Use a Range Set.
datacategory.name: Index of semantics

container.description: Group added for marker 'lf'
container.name: Lexical function label Group

datacategory.description: Used to encode the semantic networks of a language. For consistency, a Range Set should be maintained on the lexical function labels used. When formatted by MDF, these labels can be modified (and even translated) by MDF's Audience CC tables.
datacategory.name: Lexical function label

container.description: Group added for marker 'lv'
container.name: Lexical function value Group

datacategory.description: Used for the vernacular lexeme in a lexical function network. The \lv field "points to" the vernacular lexeme (a morpheme, word, or phrase) that is semantically related to the current headword as mapped or cataloged by the label in the \lf field.
datacategory.name: Lexical function value

datacategory.description: This is for giving the English gloss of the vernacular lexeme referenced by the lexical function.
datacategory.name: Lexical function gloss (E)

datacategory.description: This is for giving the national language gloss of the vernacular lexeme referenced by the lexical function.
datacategory.name: Lexical function gloss (n)

datacategory.description: This is for giving the regional language gloss of the vernacular lexeme referenced by the lexical function.
datacategory.name: Lexical function gloss (r)

datacategory.description: Used to elucidate the distinct meanings of the parts of an idiom or complex phrase in a lexical entry (\lx) or subentry (\se).
datacategory.name: Literally

datacategory.description: For any ethnographic note pertinent to the lexeme that you want separate from general notes. Capitalization and punctuation should be used as needed.
datacategory.name: Notes (anthropology)

datacategory.description: For any discourse/text analysis note pertinent to the lexeme that you want separate from general notes. Capitalization and punctuation should be used as needed.
datacategory.name: Notes (discourse)

datacategory.description: For any grammar note pertinent to the lexeme that you want separate from general notes. Capitalization and punctuation should be used as needed.
datacategory.name: Notes (grammar)

datacategory.description: For any phonology note pertinent to the lexeme that you want separate from general notes. Capitalization and punctuation should be used as needed.
datacategory.name: Notes (phonology)

datacategory.description: For any question or note for further study, pertinent to the lexeme, that you want separate from general notes. Capitalization and punctuation should be used as needed.
datacategory.name: Notes (questions)

datacategory.description: For any sociolinguistics note pertinent to the lexeme that you want separate from general notes. Capitalization and punctuation should be used as needed.
datacategory.name: Notes (sociolinguistics)

datacategory.description:
A generic dump for all personal notes about an entry, subentry, or sense. More specific note fields provide a finer differentiation to one's notes: 
p (phonology), 
g (grammar), 
d (discourse), 
a (anthropology), 
s (sociolinguistics), and 
q (questions). All "note fields" should use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Notes (general)

datacategory.description: For denoting in English any semantic and/or grammatical restrictions pertinent to the lexeme. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Only/restrictions (E)

datacategory.description: For denoting in the national language any semantic and/or grammatical restrictions pertinent to the lexeme. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Only/restrictions (n)

datacategory.description: For denoting in the regional language any semantic and/or grammatical restrictions pertinent to the lexeme. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Only/restrictions (r)

datacategory.description: This field contains the vernacular description of any semantic and/or grammatical restrictions pertinent to the lexeme or headword. This is intended for use in a monolingual dictionary, but can be used in diglot and triglot dictionaries as well. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Only/restrictions (v)

datacategory.description: This contains either the book and page number reference of a relevant picture (either sketched in a notebook or found in a picture book), or a link to the graphics file of a picture you want to include in your printed dictionary (see MDF documentation for how to create a link).
datacategory.name: Picture

datacategory.description: English word(s)/phrase(s); used to reverse the dictionary for an English index. If no \re field is given, the \ge field is used. If an \re * is present, the relevant entry, subentry, or sense will not be included in the reversed index. Put {space semicolon space} between multiple items, e.g. hut ; house.
datacategory.name: Reversal (E)

container.description: Group added for marker 'rf'
container.name: Reference Group

datacategory.description: Used to note the reference for the following example sentence.
datacategory.name: Reference

container.description: Group added for marker 'xv'
container.name: Example (v) Group

datacategory.description: Used to give an example or illustrative sentence in the vernacular to exemplify each separate sense and demonstrate legitimacy of translation equivalents. Should be short and natural. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Example (v)

datacategory.description: English translation of the example sentence given in the \xv field. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Example free trans. (E)

datacategory.description: National language translation of the example sentence given in the \xv field. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Example free trans. (n)

datacategory.description: Regional language translation of the example sentence given in the \xv field. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Example free trans. (r)

datacategory.description: National language word(s)/phrase(s); used to reverse the dictionary for a national audience index. If no \rn field is given, the \gn field is used. If an \rn * is present, the relevant entry, subentry, or sense will not be included in the reversed index. Put {space semicolon space} between multiple items, e.g. hut ; house.
datacategory.name: Reversal (n)

datacategory.description: Regional language word or phrase that could be used to reverse the dictionary for a regional audience. Currently MDF does not support exporting a regional audience index.
datacategory.name: Reversal (r)

datacategory.description: Used to provide a scientific name for a lexeme.
datacategory.name: Scientific name

datacategory.description: The English version of the \th field and probably the one to use first. Differentiate and catalog the semantic domains of an entry, being careful to not let the English force or mask the vernacular relations. Moving to the vernacular terms (given in \th field) as early as possible is best. Use a Range Set.
datacategory.name: Semantic domain

datacategory.description: Used to indicate the name and village of the informant who provided the data in the current entry.
datacategory.name: Source

datacategory.description: Used to reference a synonym of the lexeme, but using the \lf (lexical function) field for this is better practice.
datacategory.name: Synonym

datacategory.description: This field allows for a table or tabulated information to be added to the dictionary.
datacategory.name: Table

datacategory.description: Used for developing a vernacular-based thesaurus. It is to be labeled with the vernacular term governing the semantic domain of the entry. Sorting on this field (within Shoebox) would yield a vernacular thesaurus. Use a Range Set.
datacategory.name: Thesaurus

datacategory.description: This field should cover, in English, such information as common usage, or restrictions in usage (such as taboos) that is needed so a non-native speaker can use this lexeme properly. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Usage (E)

datacategory.description: This field should cover, in the national language, such information as common usage, or restrictions in usage (such as taboos) that is needed so a non-native speaker can use this lexeme properly. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Usage (n)

datacategory.description: This field should cover, in the regional language, such information as common usage, or restrictions in usage (such as taboos) that is needed so a non-native speaker can use this lexeme properly. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Usage (r)

datacategory.description: This field contains the vernacular description of common usage, or restrictions in usage (such as taboos) that is needed to describe the lexeme more fully. Intended for use in a monolingual dictionary, but can be used in diglot and triglot dictionaries as well. Use capitalization and punctuation as needed.
datacategory.name: Usage (v)

container.description: Group added for marker 'va'
container.name: Variant form(s) Group

datacategory.description: Where variant forms of the lexical entry or subentry can be noted (e.g. forms from another dialect or minor alternations in the focus dialect). Usually these forms occur elsewhere in the dictionary as minor entries. Comments on this field are given with the \ve, \vn, and \vr fields.
datacategory.name: Variant form(s)

datacategory.description: Where English comments can be given for the variant form.
datacategory.name: Variant comment (E)

datacategory.description: Where national language comments can be given for the variant form.
datacategory.name: Variant comment (n)

datacategory.description: Where regional language comments can be given for the variant form.
datacategory.name: Variant comment (r)

datacategory.description: English gloss to be used in word-level interlinear glossing.
datacategory.name: Word-level gloss (E)

datacategory.description: National language gloss to be used in word-level interlinear glossing.
datacategory.name: Word-level gloss (n)

datacategory.description: Regional language gloss to be used in word-level interlinear glossing.
datacategory.name: Word-level gloss (r)

datacategory.description: Used to indicate how complete or thoroughly checked an entry is. Use a Range Set.
datacategory.name: Status

datacategory.description: Underlying form for use in parsing interlinear text. Not for publication.
datacategory.name: Underlying for parse

container.description: The container for all the lexical entries of a source language within the database. A Lexicon must contain at least one lexical entry
container.name: Lexicon

container.description: Represents a word, a multi-word expression, or an affix in a given language
container.name: Lexical Entry

container.description: Represents a word form chosen by convention to designate the Lexical Entry
container.name: Lemma

container.description: Represents one variant orthography of a Form for a Lemma
container.name: Form Representation

container.description: Contains attributes that describe meanings of a lexical entry
container.name: Sense

container.description: Represents a narrative description of a Sense
container.name: Definition

container.description: Represents a narrative description of a Sense and refines or complements Definition
container.name: Statement

container.description: Represents one textual content of Statement
container.name: Text Representation

datacategory.description: The actual text
datacategory.name: text

container.description: Represents one textual content of Definition
container.name: Text Representation

datacategory.description: The actual text
datacategory.name: text

container.description: Represents an example of a Sense
container.name: Context

container.description: Represents one textual content of Context
container.name: Text Representation

datacategory.description: The actual text
datacategory.name: text

datacategory.description: Refers to one sense. For the sake of refrential integrity this data category should not be removed from the schema

datacategory.description: Refers to one lexical entry. For the sake of refrential integrity this data category should not be removed from the schema

template.name: RELISH-LL-LMF Template with restrictions
template.description: The Default RELISH-LL-LMF structure. with embedded restrictions

container.description: The container for all the lexical entries of a source language within the database. A Lexicon must contain at least one lexical entry
container.name: Lexicon

update.info: Updating this container will make it a lexicon specific extension of the LMF model.

create.warning: Creating a container will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

update.warning: Updating this container will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

delete.warning: Deleting this container will disable the RELISH-LL-LMF export for this lexicon.

update.warning: Updating this data category will disable the RELISH-LLL-LMF export for this lexicon.

delete.warning: Deleting this data category will disable the RELISH-LLL-LMF export for this lexicon.

create.warning: Creating a data category will disable the RELISH-LLL-LMF export for this lexicon.

container.description: Represents a word, a multi-word expression, or an affix in a given language
container.name: Lexical Entry

container.description: Represents a word form chosen by convention to designate the Lexical Entry
container.name: Lemma

update.warning: The LMF core model requires a Form subclass, i.e., Lemma. Changing this container will disable the RELISH LMF export.

delete.warning: The LMF core model requires a Form subclass, i.e., Lemma, Word Form or Stem. These are all defined in the Morphology extension where Lemma is mandatory.

container.description: Represents one variant orthography of a Form for a Lemma
container.name: Form Representation

container.description: Contains attributes that describe meanings of a lexical entry
container.name: Sense

container.description: Represents a narrative description of a Sense
container.name: Definition

container.description: Represents a narrative description of a Sense and refines or complements Definition
container.name: Statement

container.description: Represents one textual content of Statement
container.name: Text Representation

datacategory.description: The actual text
datacategory.name: text

container.description: Represents one textual content of Definition
container.name: Text Representation

delete.info: The Text Representation container is part of the LMF core model.

update.info: Changing the Text Representation container will make this a lexicon specific extension of the LMF model.

datacategory.description: The actual text
datacategory.name: text

container.description: Represents an example of a Sense
container.name: Context

container.description: Represents one textual content of Context
container.name: Text Representation

datacategory.description: The actual text
datacategory.name: text

datacategory.description: Refers to one sense. For the sake of refrential integrity this data category should not be removed from the schema
datacategory.name: target

update.warning: Changing the target data category will disable the RELISH LMF export.

delete.warning: Without the target data category the RELISH LMF export can not determine to which Sense the Sense Relation refers.

datacategory.description: Refers to one lexical entry. For the sake of refrential integrity this data category should not be removed from the schema
datacategory.name: target
